questions.question: Calculate the boiling point of the solution when 4 g of MgSO₄ (M = 120 g mol⁻¹) was dissolved in 100 g of water, assuming MgSO₄ undergoes complete ionization. ($K_b$ for water = 0.52 K kg mol⁻¹)
questions.solution: MgSO₄ → Mg²⁺ + SO₄²⁻, so i = 2 (van't Hoff factor for complete dissociation into 2 ions). ΔT_b = i × K_b × m = i × K_b × (W₂ × 1000) / (M × W₁) = 2 × 0.52 × (4 × 1000) / (120 × 100) = 2 × 0.52 / 3 = 1.04 / 3 = 0.346 K. Boiling point of water T_b° = 373.15 K. T_b = 373.15 + 0.346 = 373.496 K.

questions.question:
Give reasons:
(i) SO₂ is reducing while TeO₂ is an oxidizing agent.
(ii) Nitrogen does not form pentahalide.
(iii) ICl is more reactive than I₂.
questions.correctAnswer: (i) S is more stable in +6 state so SO₂ (S in +4) acts as reducing agent; Te is more stable in +4 state so TeO₂ acts as oxidizing agent. (ii) Nitrogen lacks d-orbitals in its valence shell so cannot expand its octet. (iii) I–Cl bond is weaker and more polar than I–I bond, making ICl more reactive.
questions.solution:
(i) As we move down Group 16, the stability of the higher oxidation state decreases. Sulphur (S) is more stable in the +6 oxidation state, so SO₂ (S in +4 state) tends to get oxidised to the +6 state, acting as a reducing agent. Tellurium (Te) is more stable in the +4 oxidation state, so TeO₂ (Te in +4 state) tends to get reduced, acting as an oxidizing agent.

(ii) Nitrogen does not form pentahalide because it lacks d-orbitals in its valence shell (n = 2). To form 5 bonds, the central atom needs to expand its octet, which requires d-orbitals. Since nitrogen has no d-orbitals available, it cannot form NX₅.

(iii) In interhalogen compounds like ICl, the I–Cl bond is weaker and more polar than the I–I bond in I₂. The bond dissociation energy of I–Cl is lower than that of I–I, making ICl more reactive. Also, the polarity of the I–Cl bond facilitates reactions with both nucleophiles and electrophiles.

questions.question:
Write the final product(s) in each of the following reactions:

(a) $\text{CH}_3\text{-C(CH}_3)_2\text{-O-CH}_3 + \text{HI} \longrightarrow$

(b) $\text{CH}_3\text{-CH}_2\text{-CH(OH)-CH}_3 \xrightarrow{\text{Cu/573 K}}$

(c) $\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{-OH} \xrightarrow{\text{(i) CHCl}_3 + \text{aq. NaOH}, \text{(ii) H}^+}$
questions.correctAnswer: (a) CH₃OH + (CH₃)₃C-I (tert-butyl iodide) (b) CH₃CH₂-CO-CH₃ (Butanone/Methyl ethyl ketone) (c) o-HO-C₆H₄-CHO (Salicylaldehyde/2-hydroxybenzaldehyde)
questions.solution:
(a) When a mixed ether (tert-butyl methyl ether) reacts with HI, the cleavage occurs at the bond between oxygen and the more substituted (tertiary) carbon via S_N1 mechanism, since the tertiary carbocation is more stable. This gives tert-butyl iodide and methanol.

(b) A secondary alcohol (butan-2-ol) on dehydrogenation over copper catalyst at 573 K gives the corresponding ketone (butanone/methyl ethyl ketone).

(c) This is the Reimer–Tiemann reaction. Phenol reacts with CHCl₃ in the presence of aqueous NaOH, followed by acidification, to give salicylaldehyde (2-hydroxybenzaldehyde) as the major product.

questions.question:
Give reasons for the following:
(i) Aniline does not undergo Friedel-Crafts reaction.
(ii) (CH₃)₂NH is more basic than (CH₃)₃N in aqueous solution.
(iii) Primary amines have higher boiling point than tertiary amines.
questions.correctAnswer: (i) Aniline reacts with AlCl₃ to form a salt, which deactivates the ring. (ii) The dimethylammonium ion is better solvated by water through hydrogen bonding than the trimethylammonium ion. (iii) Primary amines can form intermolecular hydrogen bonds via N–H bonds; tertiary amines cannot.
questions.solution:
(i) The Friedel–Crafts reaction uses AlCl₃ as a Lewis acid catalyst. Aniline (a strong Lewis base) reacts with AlCl₃ to form a salt (C₆H₅NH₃⁺·AlCl₄⁻). This positive charge on the nitrogen atom strongly deactivates the benzene ring towards electrophilic substitution. As a result, aniline does not undergo the Friedel–Crafts reaction.

(ii) In aqueous solution, the basicity depends on the +I effect of alkyl groups and solvation of the conjugate acid by water through hydrogen bonding. Although (CH₃)₃N has a greater +I effect than (CH₃)₂NH, the trimethylammonium ion has fewer N–H bonds available for hydrogen bonding with water compared to the dimethylammonium ion. Therefore, the cation of (CH₃)₂NH is better solvated, making (CH₃)₂NH more basic than (CH₃)₃N in aqueous solution.

(iii) Primary amines (R–NH₂) have two N–H bonds and can form extensive intermolecular hydrogen bonds, requiring more energy to overcome these interactions. Tertiary amines (R₃N) have no N–H bond and therefore cannot form intermolecular hydrogen bonds. As a result, more energy is required to separate primary amine molecules, giving them a higher boiling point than tertiary amines.

questions.question:
How do you convert:
(i) Chlorobenzene to biphenyl
(ii) Propene to 1-iodopropane
(iii) 2-Bromobutane to but-2-ene
questions.correctAnswer: (i) 2C₆H₅Cl + 2Na → C₆H₅-C₆H₅ + 2NaCl (Wurtz-Fittig reaction) (ii) CH₃-CH=CH₂ → (HBr/peroxide) → CH₃CH₂CH₂Br → (NaI/acetone) → CH₃CH₂CH₂I (iii) CH₃CHBrCH₂CH₃ → (Alc. KOH) → CH₃CH=CHCH₃
questions.solution:
(i) This is the Wurtz–Fittig reaction, where aryl halides react with sodium metal in dry ether to give biaryl compounds: 2C₆H₅Cl + 2Na → C₆H₅-C₆H₅ + 2NaCl.

(ii) First, propene reacts with HBr in the presence of peroxide (anti-Markovnikov addition) to give 1-bromopropane. Then, 1-bromopropane undergoes a Finkelstein reaction with NaI in acetone to give 1-iodopropane.

(iii) 2-Bromobutane undergoes dehydrohalogenation (elimination) with alcoholic KOH (a strong base) to give but-2-ene (major product, following Saytzeff's rule).

alternativeQuestion.question:
Write the major product(s) in the following:

(i) p-NO₂-C₆H₄-CH₂CH₃ reacted with Br₂ under UV light

(ii) $2\text{CH}_3\text{-CHCl-CH}_3 \xrightarrow{\text{Na, dry ether}}$

(iii) $\text{CH}_3\text{-CH}_2\text{-Br} \xrightarrow{\text{AgCN}}$
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(i) In the presence of Br₂ and UV light (free radical conditions), halogenation occurs preferentially at the benzylic position due to the greater stability of the benzylic radical. The NO₂ group does not affect this free radical reaction. Product: p-NO₂-C₆H₄-CHBr-CH₃.

(ii) This is the Wurtz reaction. Two molecules of 2-chloropropane react with Na metal in dry ether to give 2,3-dimethylbutane: CH₃-CH(CH₃)-CH(CH₃)-CH₃.

(iii) AgCN is a covalent compound and reacts through the carbon end (since Ag makes CN more covalent). The carbon of CN attacks the carbon of the alkyl halide, giving an isocyanide (R–NC), not a nitrile. Product: CH₃CH₂NC (ethyl isocyanide).

questions.question:
(i) What is the role of Sulphur in the vulcanization of rubber?

(ii) Identify the monomers in the following polymer: $\left[\text{-O-CH}_2\text{-CH}_2\text{-O-}\overset{O}{\overset{\|}{C}}\text{-}\langle\text{benzene ring}\rangle\text{-}\overset{O}{\overset{\|}{C}}\text{-}\right]_n$

(iii) Arrange the following polymers in the increasing order of their intermolecular forces: Terylene, Polythene, Neoprene
questions.correctAnswer: (i) Sulphur introduces –S–S– (polysulphide) crosslinks between polymer chains, making rubber harder and more elastic. (ii) Monomers: Ethylene glycol (HO-CH₂-CH₂-OH) and Terephthalic acid (HOOC-C₆H₄-COOH). (iii) Neoprene < Polythene < Terylene
questions.solution:
(i) During vulcanization, sulphur introduces –S–S– (polysulphide) crosslinks between adjacent polymer chains of natural rubber. These crosslinks restrict the free movement of the chains relative to one another, making the rubber harder, stronger, and more elastic with greater resistance to heat and chemicals.

(ii) This polymer is Terylene (PET — polyethylene terephthalate), formed by the condensation polymerization of ethylene glycol (HO-CH₂-CH₂-OH) and terephthalic acid (HOOC-C₆H₄-COOH).

(iii) Neoprene is an elastomer with very weak intermolecular forces (weakest, most flexible). Polythene is a thermoplastic with moderate van der Waals forces. Terylene is a condensation polymer (polyester) with strong dipole–dipole interactions and partial hydrogen bonding (strongest). Order: Neoprene < Polythene < Terylene.

questions.question:
(i) Write the structural difference between starch and cellulose.
(ii) What type of linkage is present in nucleic acids?
(iii) Give one example each for fibrous protein and globular protein.
questions.correctAnswer: (i) Starch: α-D-glucose units with α-1,4 (and α-1,6 in amylopectin) glycosidic linkages; Cellulose: β-D-glucose units with β-1,4 glycosidic linkages, strictly linear. (ii) Phosphodiester linkage. (iii) Fibrous: Silk (fibroin)/Keratin; Globular: Egg albumin/Haemoglobin/Insulin.
questions.solution:
(i) Starch has glucose monomers in α-configuration (α-D-glucose), composed of amylose (linear, α-1,4 linkages) and amylopectin (branched, α-1,4 and α-1,6 linkages). Cellulose has glucose monomers in β-configuration (β-D-glucose), joined by β-1,4-glycosidic linkages, strictly linear and unbranched.

(ii) Phosphodiester linkage — the 3′-hydroxyl group of one nucleotide is linked to the 5′-phosphate group of the next nucleotide through a phosphate ester bond, forming the backbone of the nucleic acid strand.

(iii) Fibrous protein: Silk (fibroin)/Keratin. Globular protein: Egg albumin/Haemoglobin/Insulin.

questions.question:
(a) For the complex $[\text{Fe(H}_2\text{O)}_6]^{3+}$, write the hybridization, magnetic character and spin of the complex. (At. number: Fe = 26)

(b) Draw one of the geometrical isomers of the complex $[\text{Pt(en)}_2\text{Cl}_2]^{2+}$ which is optically inactive.
questions.correctAnswer: (a) Hybridization: sp³d²; Magnetic character: strongly paramagnetic (5 unpaired electrons); Spin: High spin. (b) Trans isomer of [Pt(en)₂Cl₂]²⁺ (with Cl atoms trans to each other) is optically inactive.
questions.solution:
(a) Fe has atomic number 26: [Ar] 3d⁶ 4s². Fe³⁺ (loses 3 electrons): [Ar] 3d⁵. H₂O is a weak field ligand → does not cause pairing of electrons. All 5 d-electrons remain unpaired in the 3d⁵ configuration. The 4s, 4p, and 4d orbitals are used for hybridization → sp³d² (outer orbital complex, octahedral geometry). 5 unpaired electrons → strongly paramagnetic → high spin complex.

(b) [Pt(en)₂Cl₂]²⁺ has two geometrical isomers. The trans isomer (two Cl atoms trans to each other, two en ligands on opposite sides) has a plane of symmetry and is optically inactive. The cis isomer is optically active (has no plane of symmetry, exists as non-superimposable mirror images).

questions.question:
Due to a hectic and busy schedule, Mr. Singh started taking junk food in the lunch break and slowly became habitual of eating food irregularly to excel in his field. One day during a meeting he felt severe chest pain and fell down. Mr. Khanna, a close friend of Mr. Singh, took him to the doctor immediately. The doctor diagnosed that Mr. Singh was suffering from acidity and prescribed some medicines. Mr. Khanna advised him to eat home-made food and change his lifestyle by doing yoga, meditation and some physical exercise. Mr. Singh followed his friend's advice and after a few days he started feeling better.

After reading the above passage, answer the following:
(i) What are the values (at least two) displayed by Mr. Khanna?
(ii) What are antacids? Give one example.
(iii) Would it be advisable to take antacids for a long period of time? Give reason.
questions.correctAnswer: (i) Caring nature and supportive/helpful attitude. (ii) Antacids neutralize excess HCl in the stomach; example: Al(OH)₃/Mg(OH)₂ mixture (milk of magnesia) or NaHCO₃. (iii) No; prolonged use can make stomach contents alkaline, triggering more acid production and causing side effects.
questions.solution:
(i) The two values displayed by Mr. Khanna are: 1. Caring nature — He immediately took Mr. Singh to the doctor in an emergency. 2. Supportive/helpful attitude — He advised Mr. Singh to adopt a healthier lifestyle, showing concern for his long-term well-being.

(ii) Antacids are medications used to neutralize excess hydrochloric acid (HCl) in the stomach, thereby reducing stomach acidity and relieving symptoms like acidity, heartburn, and indigestion. Example: A mixture of aluminium hydroxide [Al(OH)₃] and magnesium hydroxide [Mg(OH)₂] (commonly known as milk of magnesia). Other examples include sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃) and ranitidine.

(iii) No, it is not advisable to take antacids for a long period of time. Reason: Excessive and prolonged use of antacids can make the stomach contents alkaline, which triggers the stomach to produce even more acid (rebound effect), worsening the condition. Additionally, long-term use can cause side effects such as constipation (Al-based), diarrhoea (Mg-based), or electrolyte imbalances.

questions.question:
(i) What type of isomerism is shown by $[Co(NH_3)_5ONO]Cl_2$?

(ii) On the basis of crystal field theory, write the electronic configuration for $d^4$ ion if $\Delta_0 < P$.

(iii) Write the hybridization and shape of $[Fe(CN)_6]^{3-}$.
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) Linkage isomerism
(ii) $t_{2g}^3\ e_g^1$
(iii) Hybridisation: $d^2sp^3$, Shape: Octahedral
questions.solution:
(i) It shows linkage isomerism:
$$[Co(NH_3)_5ONO]Cl_2 \quad \text{and} \quad [Co(NH_3)_5NO_2]Cl_2$$

(ii) If $\Delta_0 < P$ (weak field ligand), pairing does not occur:
$$d^4 \rightarrow t_{2g}^3\ e_g^1$$

(iii) $[Fe(CN)_6]^{3-}$
- Hybridisation: $d^2sp^3$
- Shape: Octahedral

questions.question:
Predict the products of the following reactions:

(i) $CH_3 - C(=O) - CH_3 \xrightarrow{H_2N - NHCONH_2} ?$

(ii) $C_6H_5 - CH_2 - CH_3 \xrightarrow{(a)\ KMnO_4/KOH} \xrightarrow{(b)\ H^+} ?$

(iii) Benzoic acid (benzene ring with $-COOH$ group) $\xrightarrow{conc.\ HNO_3/H_2SO_4}$ ?
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) $CH_3 - C(=N - NHCONH_2) - CH_3 + H_2O$ (Semicarbazone)
(ii) $C_6H_5 - COOH$ (Benzoic acid)
(iii) $m$-nitrobenzoic acid (3-nitrobenzoic acid)
questions.solution:
(i) $$CH_3 - C(=O) - CH_3 \xrightarrow{H_2N-NHCONH_2} CH_3 - C(=N - NHCONH_2) - CH_3 + H_2O$$
(Semicarbazone formation)

(ii) $$C_6H_5 - CH_2 - CH_3 \xrightarrow{(a)\ KMnO_4 \\ (b)\ H^+} C_6H_5 - COOH$$
KMnO4 oxidises the side chain to carboxylic acid.

(iii) Benzoic acid $\xrightarrow{conc.\ HNO_3/H_2SO_4}$ 3-nitrobenzoic acid ($m$-nitrobenzoic acid)
The $-COOH$ group is a meta director, so nitration occurs at the meta position.

questions.question:
Write the names and structures of the monomers of the following polymers:

(i) Nylon-6,6
(ii) Bakelite
(iii) Polystyrene
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) Adipic acid: $HOOC-(CH_2)_4-COOH$ and Hexamethylenediamine: $H_2N-(CH_2)_6-NH_2$
(ii) Phenol: $C_6H_5OH$ and Formaldehyde: $HCHO$
(iii) Styrene: $C_6H_5 - CH = CH_2$
questions.solution:
(i) Nylon-6,6 monomers:
- Adipic acid: $HOOC-(CH_2)_4-COOH$
- Hexamethylenediamine: $H_2N-(CH_2)_6-NH_2$

(ii) Bakelite monomers:
- Phenol: $C_6H_5OH$
- Formaldehyde: $HCHO$

(iii) Polystyrene monomer:
- Styrene: $C_6H_5 - CH = CH_2$ (vinylbenzene)

questions.question:
(i) Which one of the following is a disaccharide: starch, maltose, fructose, glucose?

(ii) What is the difference between acidic amino acid and basic amino acid?

(iii) Write the name of the linkage joining two nucleotides.
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) Maltose
(ii) Acidic amino acid has more $-COOH$ groups; basic amino acid has more $-NH_2$ groups
(iii) Phosphodiester linkage
questions.solution:
(i) Maltose is a disaccharide.

(ii) 
- Acidic amino acid: Contains more $-COOH$ groups than $-NH_2$ groups (i.e., $-COOH > -NH_2$).
- Basic amino acid: Contains more $-NH_2$ groups than $-COOH$ groups (i.e., $-NH_2 > -COOH$).

(iii) Phosphodiester linkage joins two nucleotides in a nucleic acid chain.

questions.question: Vapour pressure of water at 20°C is 17.5 mm Hg. Calculate the vapour pressure of water at 20°C when 15 g of glucose (Molar mass $= 180\ g\ mol^{-1}$) is dissolved in 150 g of water.
questions.correctAnswer: $P_s = 17.325\ \text{mm Hg}$
questions.solution:
Given:
$$P_A^* = 17.5\ \text{mm Hg}, \quad W_A = 150\ \text{g}, \quad M_A = 18\ \text{g mol}^{-1}$$
$$W_B = 15\ \text{g}, \quad M_B = 180\ \text{g mol}^{-1}$$

Using Raoult's Law:
$$\frac{P_A^* - P_s}{P_A^*} = \frac{W_B \times M_A}{M_B \times W_A}$$

$$\frac{17.5 - P_s}{17.5} = \frac{15 \times 18}{180 \times 150} = \frac{270}{27000} = 0.01$$

$$17.5 - P_s = 0.175$$

$$P_s = 17.325\ \text{mm Hg}$$

questions.question:
Examine the given defective crystal showing alternating $X^+$ and $Y^-$ ions, with one $Y^-$ ion replaced by an electron ($e^-$) at one site in the lattice.

Answer the following questions:

(i) Is the above defect stoichiometric or non-stoichiometric?
(ii) Write the term used for the electron occupied site.
(iii) Give an example of the compound which shows this type of defect.
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) Non-stoichiometric defect
(ii) F-Centre
(iii) NaCl in the presence of excess sodium (Na vapour)
questions.solution:
(i) Non-stoichiometric defect — the ratio of cations to anions is no longer stoichiometric.

(ii) F-Centre (Farbenzentrum / Colour Centre) — an anionic site occupied by an unpaired electron.

(iii) NaCl in the presence of excess sodium (Na vapour) shows this type of defect. When NaCl is heated in Na vapour, Na atoms deposit on the surface and Cl⁻ ions diffuse to the surface, leaving anionic vacancies which are occupied by electrons.

questions.question:
How do you convert the following:

(i) Prop-1-ene to Propan-2-ol
(ii) Bromobenzene to 2-bromoacetophenone
(iii) 2-bromobutane to But-2-ene
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) $CH_3 - CH = CH_2 \xrightarrow{H^+/H_2O} CH_3 - CH(OH) - CH_3$
(ii) Bromobenzene $\xrightarrow{C_6H_5COCl,\ An.\ AlCl_3}$ 2-bromoacetophenone
(iii) $CH_3 - CH_2 - CH(Br) - CH_3 \xrightarrow{Alc.\ KOH} CH_3 - CH = CH - CH_3$
questions.solution:
(i) Prop-1-ene to Propan-2-ol:
$$CH_3 - CH = CH_2 \xrightarrow{H^+/H_2O} CH_3 - CH(OH) - CH_3$$
By acid-catalysed hydration following Markovnikov's rule.

(ii) Bromobenzene to 2-bromoacetophenone:
Bromobenzene $\xrightarrow{C_6H_5COCl,\ An.\ AlCl_3}$ 2-bromoacetophenone
Friedel-Crafts acylation of bromobenzene. The $-Br$ group directs to ortho/para positions.

(iii) 2-bromobutane to But-2-ene:
$$CH_3 - CH_2 - CH(Br) - CH_3 \xrightarrow{Alc.\ KOH} CH_3 - CH = CH - CH_3$$
Dehydrohalogenation (E2 elimination) with alcoholic KOH.

alternativeQuestion.question:
What happens when:

(i) Ethyl chloride is treated with NaI in the presence of acetone
(ii) Chlorobenzene is treated with Na metal in the presence of dry ether
(iii) Methyl chloride is treated with KNO₂?

Write chemical equations in support of your answer.
alternativeQuestion.correctAnswer:
(i) $C_2H_5Cl + NaI \xrightarrow{acetone} C_2H_5I + NaCl$
(ii) $2C_6H_5Cl + 2Na \xrightarrow{dry\ ether} C_6H_5 - C_6H_5 + 2NaCl$ (Wurtz-Fittig reaction)
(iii) $CH_3Cl + KNO_2 \longrightarrow CH_3 - ONO + KCl$ (Methyl nitrite)
alternativeQuestion.solution:
(i) Finkelstein reaction:
$$C_2H_5Cl + NaI \xrightarrow{\text{acetone}} C_2H_5I + NaCl$$
NaI is soluble in acetone while NaCl precipitates out, driving the reaction forward.

(ii) Wurtz-Fittig reaction:
$$2C_6H_5Cl + 2Na \xrightarrow{\text{dry ether}} C_6H_5 - C_6H_5 + 2NaCl$$
Biphenyl is formed.

(iii) Reaction with KNO₂ (oxygen attack as it is ambident nucleophile):
$$CH_3Cl + KNO_2 \longrightarrow CH_3 - ONO + KCl$$
Methyl nitrite is formed because $KNO_2$ acts as nucleophile through oxygen.

questions.question:
Give reasons for the following:

(i) p-nitrophenol is more acidic than p-methylphenol.

(ii) Bond length of C–O bond in phenol is shorter than that in methanol.

(iii) $(CH_3)_3C - Br$ on reaction with sodium methoxide $(Na^+{^-}OCH_3)$ gives alkene as the main product and an ether.
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) $-NO_2$ stabilises phenoxide ion; $-CH_3$ destabilises it.
(ii) C-O bond in phenol has partial double bond character due to resonance.
(iii) $(CH_3)_3CBr$ is 3° alkyl halide favouring E2 elimination over $S_N2$ with bulky base.
questions.solution:
(i) p-Nitrophenol is more acidic because the $-NO_2$ group has $-I$ and $-M$ (electron-withdrawing) effects, which stabilise the phenoxide ion formed after loss of proton. The $-CH_3$ group in p-methylphenol has $+I$ and $+M$ effects, which destabilise the phenoxide ion, making it less acidic.

(ii) Due to resonance in phenol, the C–O bond acquires partial double bond character. The lone pair on oxygen is delocalized into the benzene ring, giving the C–O bond partial double bond character. In methanol, no such resonance exists. Therefore, the C–O bond in phenol is shorter than in methanol.

(iii) Since $(CH_3)_3CBr$ is a tertiary alkyl halide, the bulky base/nucleophile $CH_3O^-$ cannot easily attack the highly hindered tertiary carbon (steric hindrance). Therefore, it preferentially undergoes elimination reaction (E2) to give 2-methylpropene as the major product, with methyl tert-butyl ether as the minor product:
$$(CH_3)_3C - Br + CH_3O^-Na^+ \longrightarrow H_3C - C(=CH_2) - CH_3 + NaBr + CH_3OH$$

questions.question:
Calculate $E^0_{cell}$ and $\Delta_r G^0$ for the following reaction at 25°C:

$$A^{2+} + B^+ \longrightarrow A^{3+} + B$$

Given: $K_c = 10^{10}$, $1\ F = 96500\ C\ mol^{-1}$
questions.correctAnswer: $\Delta G^\circ = -5.7 \times 10^4\ J\ mol^{-1}$ and $E^\circ_{cell} = 5.9 \times 10^{-1}\ V$
questions.solution:
Step 1: Calculate $\Delta G^0$
$$\Delta G^\circ = -2.303\ RT \log K_c$$
$$\Delta G^\circ = -2.303 \times 8.314 \times 298 \times \log 10^{10}$$
$$\Delta G^\circ = -2.303 \times 8.314 \times 298 \times 10$$
$$\Delta G^\circ = -57058.483\ J\ mol^{-1} \approx -5.7 \times 10^4\ J\ mol^{-1}$$

Step 2: Calculate $E^0_{cell}$
Using $\Delta G^\circ = -nFE^\circ_{cell}$, where $n = 1$:
$$E^\circ_{cell} = -\frac{\Delta G^\circ}{nF} = \frac{-(-5.7 \times 10^4)}{1 \times 96500}$$
$$E^\circ_{cell} = 5.9 \times 10^{-1}\ V$$

questions.question: Define adsorption with an example. Why is adsorption exothermic in nature? Write the types of adsorption based on the nature of forces between adsorbate and adsorbent.
questions.correctAnswer: Adsorption is accumulation of molecular species at the surface rather than in the bulk. It is exothermic because energy is released during bond formation. Types: Physisorption (van der Waals forces) and Chemisorption (chemical bonds).
questions.solution:
Definition of Adsorption:
The accumulation of molecular species at the surface rather than in the bulk of a solid or liquid is called adsorption.

Example: Water molecules adsorbed by silica gel.

Why adsorption is exothermic:
During the adsorption process, there is a force of attraction between the adsorbate and adsorbent. When these bonds form, energy is released. Hence adsorption is always exothermic in nature ($\Delta H < 0$).

Types of Adsorption:
(a) Physisorption: Weak van der Waals forces between adsorbate and adsorbent.
(b) Chemisorption: Strong chemical (covalent/ionic) bonds between adsorbate and adsorbent.

questions.question:
Seeing the growing cases of diabetes and depression among young children, Mr. Lugani, the principal of one reputed school organised a seminar in which he invited parents and principals. They all resolved this issue by strictly banning junk food in schools and introducing healthy snacks and drinks like soup, lassi, milk, etc. in school canteens. They also decided to make compulsory half an hour of daily physical activities for the students in the morning assembly. After six months, Mr. Lugani conducted the health survey in most of the schools and discovered a tremendous improvement in the health of the students.

After reading the above passage, answer the following questions:

(i) What are the values (at least two) displayed by Mr. Lugani?
(ii) As a student, how can you spread awareness about this issue?
(iii) What are antidepressant drugs? Give an example.
(iv) Name the sweetening agent used in the preparation of sweets for a diabetic patient.
questions.correctAnswer:
(i) Consciousness towards student health and proactive social responsibility.
(ii) Motivate peers, school presentations, social media awareness.
(iii) Chemical substances to treat depression by inhibiting degradation of neurotransmitters. Example: Phenelzine.
(iv) Saccharin
questions.solution:
(i) Values displayed by Mr. Lugani:
(a) He is very conscious towards the health of students.
(b) He is very disciplined and proactive in addressing social issues.

(ii) As a student, I would motivate my friends and classmates to adopt healthy food habits, participate in physical activity, and avoid junk food. Awareness can be spread through school presentations, social media, and peer discussions.

(iii) Antidepressant drugs are chemical substances used to treat depression by inhibiting the enzymes that catalyse the degradation of neurotransmitters (e.g., norepinephrine and serotonin) in the brain.
Example: Phenelzine

(iv) Saccharin (ortho-sulphobenzimide) — it is 550 times sweeter than cane sugar and is excreted unchanged in urine, making it safe for diabetic patients.
